Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Biomanufacturing: Engineered hydrogel capsules for controlled scalable cultures of pluripotent stem cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Banerjee, Ipsita
Proposal Number: 1547618

Human pluripotent stem cells (hPSCs) possess the unique capability of giving rise to many different cell types in the body and hence hold great potential in transforming cell-based therapies, disease modeling, and drug discovery. A vital step in the path to clinical translation of hPSCs is to implement reproducible, homogenous, and scalable cell culture and differentiation technologies. The primary challenge in scalable cultures of hPSCs is the maintenance of high viability and proliferation without compromising the ability of the cells to differentiate into therapeutically relevant tissue types. The objective of this research is to design a novel materials-based platform to achieve such scalable culture of hPSCs for biomanufacturing. Besides scale-up, the designed system is expected to produce homogenous aggregates of uniform size, which will significantly reduce variability in differentiation and lead to increased fidelity in biomanufacturing.

Currently, the ubiquitous scale-up platform of hPSCs is based on aggregate suspension cultures which have the potential to produce hPSCs at clinically relevant scales. Substantial challenges still remain with this system, including low viability of initial seeding population, spontaneous cell aggregation leading to inhomogeneous and non-uniform aggregates, and uncontrolled and dynamic shear force on the cell surface. These challenges can restrict scalability and introduce unwanted and unnecessary variability on differentiation. In this work, the investigators propose to overcome these shortcomings through the design of novel biomimetic hydrogel capsules for scalable culture of hPSCs. Specifically, they propose to incorporate synthetic bioactive peptides mimicking cadherin and non-cadherin cell-cell interactions within three dimensional (3D) macroporous hydrogel capsules, for encapsulating and propagating hPSCs. These peptide-conjugated hydrogel capsules will be designed to mimic the cellular microenvironment by synthetically recreating cell-cell contacts through epithelial-cadherin (E-cadherin). Alternate peptide designs and combinations will be screened in an alginate array platform to select for those supporting short-term viability and proliferation. Further, macroporous capsules will be synthesized from the designed peptide-conjugated alginate to facilitate homogeneity in hPSC aggregates. The capsule design will also prevent coalescence of the aggregates. hPSCs propagated in alternate capsule designs will be characterized for long-term viability, pluripotency and scalability. Recreating cell-cell contact is expected to significantly enhance single cell viability and clonal expansion over current state-of-art of inhibiting Rho associated coiled coil protein kinase (ROCK) pathway. Furthermore, hydrogel encapsulation will protect the cells from bioreactor hydrodynamic stresses, hence removing shear-induced variations in the culture. The proposed work encompasses biomaterials, synthetic peptides, stem cells and bioprocessing, hence providing opportunities for interdisciplinary training of students from different disciplines. The PI also proposes to utilize health care relevance of this cross-disciplinary project to involve under-represented and minority students into STEM fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Human pluripotent stem cells (hPSCs) hold great potential in cell therapy, disease modeling and drug discovery. Successful implementation of hPSCs in these applications will require (i) efficient, large scale production of desired cell types, henceforth referred to as biomanufacturing and (ii) differentiation to functional cell types of interest. Currently the typical propagation of hPSCs in adherent cultures are performed on matrigel coated culture plates. On the other end, the ubiquitous scale-up platform of hPSCs is the aggregate based suspension culture which has the potential to produce hPSCs in clinically relevant scales.  The primary challenge in using matrigel for adherent culture lies in its xenogenic origin, which restricts the translational potential of cells exposed to matrigel. Challenges with suspension culture include: low viability of initial seeding population, spontaneous aggregation leading to inhomogeneous and non-uniform aggregates, and uncontrolled and dynamic shear force on the cell surface. These challenges can introduce unwanted and unnecessary variability on differentiation. Overcoming these shortcomings will be critical in establishing a controlled robust stem cell biomanufacturing platform.

The objective of this project is to meet these challenge through a materials based platform, which can support propagation of hPSCs in both adherent and suspension culture. The specific criteria for meeting these goals will be to develop a platform that (1) supports hPSC attachment and viability, (3) maintains hPSC pluripotency, and (4), retains hPSC differentiation potential. We designed a defined hydrogel system by incorporating synthetic bioactive peptides within alginate hydrogel. The designed substrate was used for both adherent 2D culture of hPSCs as well as 3D suspension culture under encapsulation. We successfully designed four alternate peptides mimicking cell to cell interaction through E Cadherin binding, and conjugated them to alginate hydrogel. We observed that each of the peptides promoted attachment and viability of the hPSCs, and they subsequently formed small colonies on or in the substrate with continued culture. It is important to note that the culture was completely devoid of matrigel and was fully defined. Furthermore, the designed substrates supported significant propagation of the hPSCs, in the range of 10 to 25 fold expansion, based on specific peptide design. The propagated hPSCs retained high pluripotency, with an enhancement of Oct4 and Nanog gene and protein expression over control cultures on matrigel. Upon spontaneous differentiation it was observed that the differentiating cell population has a higher preference for endoderm and mesoderm germ layers, as compared to ectoderm differentiation. Further induced differentiation of the propagated hPSC population towards endoderm germ layer revealed stronger upregulation of endoderm specific genes, namely Sox17 and Foxa2. While endoderm differentiation was sensitive to the specific peptide design, the differentiation on longer amino acid peptides were similar to those conducted on matrigel, which is considered to be the gold standard. Hence the peptide modified alginate substrate designed in this project could support the viability, propagation, pluripotency and differentiation potential of hPSCs and has the potential to replace matrigel from hPSC cultures.

In the next step, we incorporated the hPSCs within alginate beads in order to facilitate 3D suspension culture, towards scale up. The encapsulated hPSCs were observed to be viable upon encapsulation and grew into small colonies within the capsule. We further induced the encapsulated hPSC colonies towards pancreatic endocrine lineage and towards maturation into pancreatic beta like cells. We also maintained hPSCs in stirred suspension culture as a positive control. We observed that the hPSCs aggregates under stirred suspension culture tends to dissociate towards late stage maturation. In contrast, when the hPSCs colonies were encapsulated and matured, they remained live and aggregated all through the maturation process. Importantly, the iPSC cells consistently failed to aggregate in suspension culture and could not be cultured and matured under suspension. However they could be successfully encapsulated and propagated in our substrate, and further matured into endocrine lineage. These islet like colonies were functional, as judged by glucose responsive insulin secretion. 

Broader Impact: This project is a culmination of diverse engineering techniques, encompassing biomaterials, peptides, stem cells and bioprocessing. The developed hydrogel has the potential to replace matrigel for adherent culture of hPSCs and supplement stirred suspension cultures in scalable bioreactor platform, and hence expected to have significant impact in regenerative medicine. The health care relevance of this cross-disciplinary project was successful in attracting under-represented and minority students into STEM fields. Through this project we have trained one graduate student (Hispanic) and one undergraduate student (female, African-American). We have also received training for product commercialization through U Pitt NSF I-Corps supported program, and we have filed invention disclosure.

 


Last Modified: 01/15/2019
Modified by: Ipsita Banerjee
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Human pluripotent stem cells (hPSCs) hold great potential in cell therapy, disease modeling and drug discovery. Successful implementation of hPSCs in these applications will require (i) efficient, large scale production of desired cell types, henceforth referred to as biomanufacturing and (ii) differentiation to functional cell types of interest. Currently the typical propagation of hPSCs in adherent cultures are performed on matrigel coated culture plates. On the other end, the ubiquitous scale-up platform of hPSCs is the aggregate based suspension culture which has the potential to produce hPSCs in clinically relevant scales. The primary challenge in using matrigel for adherent culture lies in its xenogenic origin, which restricts the translational potential of cells exposed to matrigel. Challenges with suspension culture include: low viability of initial seeding population, spontaneous aggregation leading to inhomogeneous and non-uniform aggregates, and uncontrolled and dynamic shear force on the cell surface. These challenges can introduce unwanted and unnecessary variability on differentiation. Overcoming these shortcomings will be critical in establishing a controlled robust stem cell biomanufacturing platform. The objective of this project is to meet these challenge through a materials based platform, which can support propagation of hPSCs in both adherent and suspension culture. The specific criteria for meeting these goals will be to develop a platform that (1) supports hPSC attachment and viability, (3) maintains hPSC pluripotency, and (4), retains hPSC differentiation potential. We observed that each of the peptides promoted attachment and viability of the hPSCs, and they subsequently formed small colonies on or in the substrate with continued culture. It is important to note that the culture was completely devoid of matrigel and was fully defined. Furthermore, the designed substrates supported significant propagation of the hPSCs, in the range of 10 to 25 fold expansion, based on specific peptide design. The propagated hPSCs retained high pluripotency, with an enhancement of Oct4 and Nanog gene and protein expression over control cultures on matrigel. Upon spontaneous differentiation it was observed that the differentiating cell population has a higher preference for endoderm and mesoderm germ layers, as compared to ectoderm differentiation. In the next step, we incorporated the hPSCs within alginate beads in order to facilitate 3D suspension culture, towards scale up. However they could be successfully encapsulated and propagated in our substrate, and further matured into endocrine lineage. These islet like colonies were functional, as judged by glucose responsive insulin secretion. Broader Impact: This project is a culmination of diverse engineering techniques, encompassing biomaterials, peptides, stem cells and bioprocessing. The developed hydrogel has the potential to replace matrigel for adherent culture of hPSCs and supplement stirred suspension cultures in scalable bioreactor platform, and hence expected to have significant impact in regenerative medicine. The health care relevance of this cross-disciplinary project was successful in attracting under-represented and minority students into STEM fields. Through this project we have trained one graduate student (Hispanic) and one undergraduate student (female, African-American). We have also received training for product commercialization through U Pitt NSF I-Corps supported program, and we have filed invention disclosure.
